info.game_comments: 2005 Ultimate Tournament of Champions Round 3, game 6.

(1, 1).clue: This resort island off the coast of South Carolina was named for a British sea captain, not a hotelier

(3, 1).clue: Fourth & retaining are types of this

(5, 1).clue: Tournament, as well as this 5-letter word, can be used to describe mounted combat between medieval knights

(6, 1).clue: In 1996 this Asian-American teen won her first national championship in figure skating

(1, 2).clue: Not surprisingly there's a Napoleon & a Bonaparte Museum on this island where Napoleon was born

(2, 2).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew wanders through an ancient olive pressery on Naxos, Greece.)  Cold-pressed olive oil is naturally low in this, & is classified by its ascending level of it

(3, 2).clue: A baseball slugger or anyone going for broke is "swinging for" these

(4, 2).clue: A single San Quentin dweller in solitary

(5, 2).clue: Geoffroi de Purelli wrote the first knights' tournament guidelines in this Norman Invasion year

(6, 2).clue: Now an actor, in 1976 he was the European Professional Karate Assoc. middleweight champion

(1, 3).clue: This country's larger islands include Mindoro & Leyte

(2, 3).clue: Olive oil is high in this type of fat whose name tells you it has only one type of a certain bond per molecule

(3, 3).clue: Sherry Lansing of Paramount & Brenda Barnes of Pepsi crashed (metaphorically) through this brittle barrier

(4, 3).clue: This Nestle product was introduced in 1961

(5, 3).clue: Sir Lionel is killed during a tournament in this musical but is later miraculously revived

(6, 3).clue: In 1892 this gentleman knocked out John L. Sullivan to become the new heavyweight champion

(1, 4).clue: More than 150 islands make up this country, the last remaining kingdom in Polynesia

(2, 4).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew sits down to an al fresco meal in Greece.)  I've ordered this type of black olive so prized that the Spartans annexed Messenia to get the supply

(3, 4).clue: Soft to the touch, it's the proverbial barrier to entering the hottest clubs

(5, 4).clue: From Old French for "to mix", this no-holds-barred medieval group combat contest was basically mob against mob

(6, 4).clue: The author of about 40 books, he was world bridge champion in 1950

(1, 5).clue: Let's drink a toast to this Caribbean island; it's the largest in the Netherlands Antilles

(2, 5).clue: This thick spread made from capers & black olives hails from Provence

(3, 5).clue: From the Latin "palus" come the words "pale", a stake or picket, & this word for a barrier made up of pales

(5, 5).clue: Celebrated until the 17th c., the last knights' tournaments to survive involved "running at" these to spear them

(6, 5).clue: Formula One champion Ayrton Senna from this South American country began driving at age 4

(1, 1).clue: In the 16th century, Dr. Ambroise Paré began treating wounds with egg yolk balm instead of with boiling this

(3, 1).clue: In 1868 Red Cloud agreed to accept for this tribe a reservation in the Dakota Territory nearly as big as Pennsylvania

(4, 1).clue: Vittorio Orlando represented this country at the meeting of the "Big Four" leaders in Paris in 1919

(5, 1).clue: Mary Ann Evans wrote under this pseudonym, partly to honor her lover

(6, 1).clue: This blonde "Casino" actress serves as the rock associated with the coronation of Scottish kings

(1, 2).clue: The greatest surgeon of his time, Dr. Paré began his career as the apprentice to this type of professional

(3, 2).clue: In 1820 Edwin James climbed a Colorado peak that was then named for him; today we call it this

(4, 2).clue: It's the stadium where  the Capital One Bowl is held each January in Orlando, Florida

(5, 2).clue: Last name of Sidonie-Gabrielle, also her pen name

(6, 2).clue: Hit duet for Sonny & Cher that was a pro golfer who married a pro wrestler in 1938

(1, 3).clue: Paré rejected such methods of this ancient physician as dropping the patient off a roof

(3, 3).clue: In August of 1807 this steamboat made its first run, traveling from NYC to Albany

(4, 3).clue: Orlando is the title hero/heroine of this author's 1928 time-traveling, gender-bending novel

(5, 3).clue: This Russian-American novelist published his early Russian works as V. Sirin

(6, 3).clue: Viking leader of a colorful Stendhal classic
(6, 3).correct response: Eric the Red and the Black

(1, 4).clue: Paré created trusses for patients troubled by this, doing away with an older treatment, castration

(3, 4).clue: When completed in 1855, the Point Loma Lighthouse in this Southern California city was the USA's tallest at 462 feet

(4, 4).clue: Famed Westminster Abbey organist Orlando Gibbons performed at the funeral of this Stuart King in 1625

(5, 4).clue: Playwright Jean-Baptiste Poquelin wrote under this nom de plume

(6, 4).clue: Pioneering palimony suit brought by the singer of "I Heard It Through The Grapevine"

(1, 5).clue: To prevent this, i.e. heavy bleeding, Paré tied blood vessels instead of cauterizing them with hot irons

(2, 5).clue: "The Secret Life of Buddy and Sally"

(3, 5).clue: In 1875 this Republican was elected governor of Ohio; 17 months later, he took the oath of office as president

(4, 5).clue: This word follows "Orlando" in the title of a 16th century epic poem by Ludovico Ariosto

(5, 5).clue: H.H. Munro published his stories under this potent potable name

(6, 5).clue: General nicknamed "Old Fuss and Feathers" who replaced Ari Fleischer as White House Press Secretary

(0, 0).clue: Of the 10 most populous U.S. cities, the one that shares its name with a city mentioned in Revelation
